key_work.title: Tinted film
key_work.brief_description: The most common methods of colouring early films were tinting and toning. Tinting was inspired by the translucent lighting gels used in theatre, while toning was adapted from photographic printing.

links.description: Seventy years after The Maltese Falcon gave flight to film noir, the genre hit videogames in 2011 with the release of Team Bondi and Rockstar Games’ L.A. Noire, a murder mystery set in post-WWII Los Angeles.

end.title: Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries
end.brief_description: Our lady sleuth sashays through the back lanes and jazz clubs of late-1920s Melbourne, fighting injustice with her pearl handled pistol and dagger sharp wit. Leaving a trail of admirers in her wake, our thoroughly modern heroine makes sure she enjoys every moment of her lucky life.

links.description: L.A. Noire has been criticised for its lack of female representation. Miss Fisher’s Murder Mysteries wouldn’t face the same accusation and inverts many film noir tropes to celebrate an independently wealthy, female private detective.

end.title: The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari
end.brief_description: The Cabinet of Dr Caligari is considered one of the very first horror movies, featuring an unreliable narrator and establishing horror movie tropes and styles. It’s the story of a mad hypnotist using a sleep-walker to terrorise a small town. Or is it?

links.description: Versions of Robert Wiene’s proto-horror film featured extensive tinting to communicate suspense, sickness and madness, with the frames bathed in midnight blue, eerie orange and envious green.

end.title: L.A. Confidential
end.creator_credit: Curtis Hanson, Brian Helgeland, Arnon Milchan and Michael G. Nathanson
end.brief_description: Three detectives in the corrupt and brutal L.A. police force of the 1950s use differing methods to uncover a conspiracy behind the shotgun slayings of the patrons at an all-night diner.

constellations_other.name: Monsters, murder and mystery

links.description: Set during the same time period, L.A. Noire and L.A. Confidential share the same noir themes and explore the grimy underbelly of the City of Angles. Many of the characters in L.A. Noire are similar to those in L.A. Confidential, including police captains in both media using the phrase “boyos”.

end.title: Dracula
end.creator_credit: Tod Browning, Ed Ware, Vera West, Carl Laemmle Jr., E.M. Asher, Universal Pictures, Herman Rosse, John Hoffman, Garrett Fort, Louis Bromfield and Louis Stevens
end.brief_description: British estate agent Renfield travels to Transylvania to meet with the mysterious Count Dracula, who is interested in leasing a castle in London and is, unbeknownst to Renfield, a vampire. After Dracula enslaves Renfield and drives him to insanity, the pair sail to London together, and as Dracula begins preying on London socialites, the two become the subject of study for a supernaturalist professor, Abraham Van Helsing.

links.description: Robert Wiene’s silent German Expressionist film about a hypnotist forcing a sleepwalker to murder is considered the first horror movie and inspired the Hollywood horrors of the 1930s and 40s, including Dracula.

end.title: The Long Goodbye
end.creator_credit: Robert Altman, Elliott Kastner and Jerry Bick
end.brief_description: Detective Philip Marlowe helps his friend Terry Lennox get to the Mexican border late one night. When he makes his way back home, he finds police waiting for Terry who has murdered his own wife.

links.description: While film noir thrillers of the 1940s and 50s dealt primarily with psychological treachery and duplicity, spiritual successors like Robert Altman’s neo-noir The Long Goodbye focused on sociological issues of the post-Vietnam and post-Watergate era.

links.description: The success of early horror films inspired the strange angles and shadows common in German Expressionism to be adopted by film noir to portray a pessimistic world bristling with crime, anti-heroes and femme fatales. John Huston’s The Maltese Falcon is considered a landmark early work in the genre.
